awd_titl_txt: Conference: Historical Memory: A Puget Sound Symposium on American Movements that Advocated Applying Selective Breeding Science to Humans
awd_abstract_narration:
This award supports a symposium on American movements that have advocated for the controversial and often grossly abusive practice of applying selective breeding science to human rather than animal populations. Such movements have been susceptible to gross abuses such as those that occurred during WW2. The focus of the symposium is on one such movement. It is to be held on March 28, 2020 at the University of Puget Sound. The symposium is inspired by a recent discovery by one of the university’s students that the namesake of its Slater Museum of Natural History Museum, James R. Slater, taught a course that focused positively on the selective breeding of humans from 1920-1951. The symposium organizers have invited some of the foremost historians in this issue to Puget Sound to facilitate the development of an historical perspective on the controversial movement with particular attention to the biology curricula of liberal arts colleges. The symposium has tremendous potential for specific beneficial societal outcomes through providing a venue for thoughtful, historically-informed discussions of difficult histories and issues that are very timely. The organizers will share the results of the symposium via an educational website and museum exhibit; the symposium discussions will provide a foundation for the creation of a both a physical and online exhibit on the history of American movements that have advocated selective breeding of humans in biology curricula at the local, national and international level to be hosted by the Slater Museum of Natural History. 
    
The symposium, "American Movements that Advocated Applying Selective Breeding Science to Humans," will advance knowledge by bringing together established scholars, up-and-coming scholars, and a new generation of undergraduate biology students keen to draw on history in their efforts to ensure attention to social justice as they pursue lives in science. The symposium will serve to provide a venue for complex, difficult conversations regarding the history of selective breeding of humans and American biology, the problems of historical memory, and who is commemorated in the history of American science and why. Within the history of science, the history of the selective breeding of humans has been a highly productive field over the past few generations. The symposium will bring together scholars from a range of disciplines, including historians and biologists, to examine the history of selective breeding of humans as well as more general problems concerning commemoration and historical memory on college campuses. The potential of these interdisciplinary conversations to create new insights and connections is large.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Like all sciences, biology tells us about the world we live in and teaches us how we can learn more about that world, including ourselves. But the discipline of biology also has a history that is problematic and at times tragic. During the opening decades of the twentieth century, many American biologists were committed to eugenics, a broad, popular, and diverse movement that held that knowledge about heredity would provide the key to social and biological progress. These biologists believed that eugenics would provide the primary means through which their discipline could make a difference in the world. The movement was pervasive in American culture and global in scope and reach. American biologists' commitment to eugenics also had a huge impact on the biology curriculum of universities across the country. By 1928, 376 college courses on eugenics existed in this country, including at our own institution, the University of Puget Sound.

This project took an historical approach to questions raised by the fact the namesake of the University of Puget Sound's Slater Museum of Natural History, James Slater, taught a course on eugenics from 1921 to 1953. In view of calls to rename the museum, this grant supported a range of efforts aimed at studying the history of eugenics, historical memory, and commemorative practices, including why and when buildings should be renamed. Several renowned experts on the history of eugenics agreed to help via a symposium planned for March 23, 2020, in support of which this grant was solicited. Unfortunately, the Covid-19 pandemic resulted in the cancellation of the in-person symposium, but intent on fulfilling the original purpose of the grant to create an educational resource that reaches beyond campus, we developed an (approved) "Revision of Use of Funds." 

This plan included several elements, but most importantly the development of  a high quality website that includes talks by many of the original symposium participants, available here: https://historyofeugenics.pugetsoundmuseum.org/an-archive-exhibit/

The content of the website centers on the following questions: What was the social, political, and cultural context within which eugenics became so pervasive within American society and science? How did eugenics influence biology curricula and courses? What role did eugenics play on liberal arts campuses? What are the legacies of the eugenics movement in the American and Canadian West? How, as institutions and as individuals, can we learn from this history and its legacies? How can and should this history be included in our local and national commemorative practices and decisions with respect to key local and national figures in the history of science?

In addition to the website, upon return to in-person classes, the grant supported a range of programming during Fall 2022 centered on the relationship between the history of biology, reproductive rights, commemorative practices, public history, historical memory, eugenic aesthetics, and "scientific racism." We are still awaiting a decision on the name of the museum by the Board of Trustees, but when that is delivered we will be finalizing the framing of the website and advertising it widely as a pedagogical resource on the history of eugenics & commemorative practices to educators in biology, history, and the history of science.  

The goal of all of this work, as outlined in our original proposal, was to ask difficult questions and explore a complex past with an eye to how the challenges and complexities of that past can inform decisions in the present, both with respect to commemorative practices and how we think about the role of science in society. We believe that reckoning with prior decisions regarding how scientific expertise should be applied to social problems can create more informed and thoughtful assessments of current-day hopes and challenges. Examining this history within the context of commemorative practices (including whether buildings should be renamed) also provides a timely and important framework for thinking about how values and justifications of science change over time and why. Ultimately, doing so improves our ability to talk about competing values, technological change, and the imperatives and challenges of progress in science, especially genetic medicine. We hope we have produced a long-lived contribution to both historical and STEM education. The past holds important lessons and, in particular, can inspire humility and mindfulness as we hope for and promise great things from science.
